result.markdown:
---
title: "Hands-on Exercise 1: Geospatial Data Wrangling with R"
execute: 
  warning: false
  freeze: true
date: "2024-02-13"
---


# 1.1 Getting Started

In this exercise, I will:

-   install and load of basic R packages

-   handle geospatial files

-   plot geospatial data

## 1.1.1 Datasets

-   [Master Plan 2014 Subzone Boundary (Web)](https://beta.data.gov.sg/datasets/d_5cb80a95445f236737f6bc2bfe5f159d/view)

-   [Pre-Schools Location](https://beta.data.gov.sg/collections/2064/view)

-   [Cycling Path](https://datamall.lta.gov.sg/content/datamall/en/search_datasets.html?searchText=Cycling%20Path)

-   [Singapore Airbnb Listing CSV](http://insideairbnb.com/get-the-data/)

## 1.1.2 Installing and Loading R Packages

In this exercise, we will use the `tidyverse` and `sf` packages. The `p_load` function from the `package` will assist in installing and loading these packages.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
pacman::p_load(tidyverse, sf)
```
:::


# 1.2 Importing Geospatial Data

`st_read()` from `sf` package, can be used for shapefiles to be imported into R as a polygon feature data frame.

## 1.2.1 Master Plan 2014 Subzone Boundary

::: callout-note
-   `dsn`: filepath
-   `layer`: file name
:::


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", 
                  layer = "MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Reading layer `MP14_SUBZONE_WEB_PL' from data source 
  `C:\fathimak2020\IS415-GAA\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 323 features and 15 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
```
:::
:::


The projected CRS of `mpsz` is SVY21.

## 1.2.2 Cycling Path


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
cyclingpath = st_read(dsn="data/geospatial",
                       layer = "CyclingPathGazette")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Reading layer `CyclingPathGazette' from data source 
  `C:\fathimak2020\IS415-GAA\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 2558 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: MULTILINESTRING
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 11854.32 ymin: 28347.98 xmax: 42626.09 ymax: 48948.15
Projected CRS: SVY21
```
:::
:::


The projected CRS of `cyclingpath` is SVY21.

## 1.2.3 Pre-Schools Location


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
preschool = st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial/PreSchoolsLocation.kml")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Reading layer `PRESCHOOLS_LOCATION' from data source 
  `C:\fathimak2020\IS415-GAA\Hands-on_Ex\Hands-on_Ex01\data\geospatial\PreSchoolsLocation.kml' 
  using driver `KML'
Simple feature collection with 2290 features and 2 fields
Geometry type: POINT
Dimension:     XYZ
Bounding box:  xmin: 103.6878 ymin: 1.247759 xmax: 103.9897 ymax: 1.462134
z_range:       zmin: 0 zmax: 0
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
```
:::
:::


The Geodetic CRS of `prechool` is WGS 84.

# 1.3 Checking the Content of A Simple Feature Data Frame

## **1.3.1 Retrieve Geometries**

`st_geometry(mpsz)` displays basic information of the geometries.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_geometry(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Geometry set for 323 features 
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 2667.538 ymin: 15748.72 xmax: 56396.44 ymax: 50256.33
Projected CRS: SVY21
First 5 geometries:
```
:::
:::


## 1.3.2 View Attributes in simple feature DataFrame

`glimpse()` will retrieve each field’s datatype.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

# 1.4 Plotting Geospatial Data

`plot()` is used to visualise all attributes of `mpsz`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## 1.4.1 Geometry Plot

The code will display a plot with only the basic geometry.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(st_geometry(mpsz))
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## 1.4.2 Attribute Plot

We can also specify the column of interest to plot only the selected feature.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
plot(mpsz["PLN_AREA_N"])
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-10-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


# 1.5 Working with Map Projection

For geoprocessing with multiple geospatial datasets, we need to ensure they share a common coordinate system. Transforming a DataFrame from one coordinate system to another is known as projection transformation.

## 1.5.1 Assigning EPSG code

In `MPSZ`, the EPSG code is 9001 although it is projected in SVY21.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
st_crs(mpsz)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Coordinate Reference System:
  User input: SVY21 
  wkt:
PROJCRS["SVY21",
    BASEGEOGCRS["SVY21[WGS84]",
        DATUM["World Geodetic System 1984",
            ELLIPSOID["WGS 84",6378137,298.257223563,
                LENGTHUNIT["metre",1]],
            ID["EPSG",6326]],
        PRIMEM["Greenwich",0,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433]]],
    CONVERSION["unnamed",
        METHOD["Transverse Mercator",
            ID["EPSG",9807]],
        PARAMETER["Latitude of natural origin",1.36666666666667,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8801]],
        PARAMETER["Longitude of natural origin",103.833333333333,
            ANGLEUNIT["Degree",0.0174532925199433],
            ID["EPSG",8802]],
        PARAMETER["Scale factor at natural origin",1,
            SCALEUNIT["unity",1],
            ID["EPSG",8805]],
        PARAMETER["False easting",28001.642,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8806]],
        PARAMETER["False northing",38744.572,
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1],
            ID["EPSG",8807]]],
    CS[Cartesian,2],
        AXIS["(E)",east,
            ORDER[1],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1,
                ID["EPSG",9001]]],
        AXIS["(N)",north,
            ORDER[2],
            LENGTHUNIT["metre",1,
                ID["EPSG",9001]]]]
```
:::
:::


`st_set_crs()` can be used for EPSG code assignment to 3414.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz3414 <- st_set_crs(mpsz, 3414)
```
:::


## 1.5.2 Transforming Projection

The geographic coordinate system is not suitable for distance and area measurements. Therefore, transforming from a geographic coordinate system to a projected coordinate system is necessary. To achieve this transformation, use `st_transform()`.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
preschool3414 <- st_transform(preschool, 
                              crs = 3414)
```
:::


# 1.6 Importing and Converting Aspatial Data

## 1.6.1 Importing Aspatial Data

We get a Tibble from using the function `read_csv()`


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
listings <- read_csv("data/aspatial/listings.csv")
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
list(listings) 
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
[[1]]
# A tibble: 3,457 × 18
       id name      host_id host_name neighbourhood_group neighbourhood latitude
    <dbl> <chr>       <dbl> <chr>     <chr>               <chr>            <dbl>
 1  71609 Villa in…  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 2  71896 Home in …  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 3  71903 Home in …  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.35
 4 275343 Rental u… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 5 275344 Rental u… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 6 289234 Home in …  367042 Belinda   East Region         Tampines          1.34
 7 294281 Rental u… 1521514 Elizabeth Central Region      Newton            1.31
 8 324945 Rental u… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
 9 330095 Rental u… 1439258 Kay       Central Region      Bukit Merah       1.29
10 369141 Place to… 1521514 Elizabeth Central Region      Newton            1.31
# ℹ 3,447 more rows
# ℹ 11 more variables: longitude <dbl>, room_type <chr>, price <dbl>,
#   minimum_nights <dbl>, number_of_reviews <dbl>, last_review <date>,
#   reviews_per_month <dbl>, calculated_host_listings_count <dbl>,
#   availability_365 <dbl>, number_of_reviews_ltm <dbl>, license <chr>
```
:::
:::


*latitude* and *longitude* are the columns that we are interested to look at.

## 1.6.2 Converting from Aspatial DataFrame to Simple Feature DataFrame

Parameters for `st_as_sf()`:

-   coords: Column names for x and y coordinates

-   crs: Coordinate system in EPSG format

-   `%>%` nests `st_transform()` to convert the DataFrame into SVY21 projected CRS


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
listings_sf <- st_as_sf(listings, 
                       coords = c("longitude", "latitude"),
                       crs=4326) %>%
  st_transform(crs = 3414)
```
:::


The new sf DataFrame can be seen below.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
glimpse(listings_sf)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Rows: 3,457
Columns: 17
$ id                             <dbl> 71609, 71896, 71903, 275343, 275344, 28…
$ name                           <chr> "Villa in Singapore · ★4.44 · 2 bedroom…
$ host_id                        <dbl> 367042, 367042, 367042, 1439258, 143925…
$ host_name                      <chr> "Belinda", "Belinda", "Belinda", "Kay",…
$ neighbourhood_group            <chr> "East Region", "East Region", "East Reg…
$ neighbourhood                  <chr> "Tampines", "Tampines", "Tampines", "Bu…
$ room_type                      <chr> "Private room", "Private room", "Privat…
$ price                          <dbl> 150, 80, 80, 64, 78, 220, 85, 75, 69, 7…
$ minimum_nights                 <dbl> 92, 92, 92, 60, 60, 92, 92, 60, 60, 92,…
$ number_of_reviews              <dbl> 19, 24, 46, 20, 16, 12, 131, 17, 5, 81,…
$ last_review                    <date> 2020-01-17, 2019-10-13, 2020-01-09, 20…
$ reviews_per_month              <dbl> 0.13, 0.16, 0.30, 0.15, 0.11, 0.09, 0.9…
$ calculated_host_listings_count <dbl> 5, 5, 5, 51, 51, 5, 7, 51, 51, 7, 7, 1,…
$ availability_365               <dbl> 55, 91, 91, 183, 183, 54, 365, 183, 183…
$ number_of_reviews_ltm          <dbl> 0, 0, 0, 0, 3, 0, 0, 1, 2, 0, 0, 0, 0, …
$ license                        <chr> NA, NA, NA, "S0399", "S0399", NA, NA, "…
$ geometry                       <POINT [m]> POINT (41972.5 36390.05), POINT (…
```
:::
:::


As seen, *longtitude* and *latitude* columns are dropped, and a geometry column is added.

# 1.7 Geoprocessing

## 1.7.1 Buffering

> **Scenario**
>
> The authority intends to enhance the existing cycling path. To achieve this, they must obtain 5 meters of reserved land on both sides of the current cycling path. Your responsibility is to ascertain the extent of the land that needs to be acquired and calculate its total area.

`st_buffer()` is used to calculate buffers.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
buffer_cycling <- st_buffer(cyclingpath, 
                            dist=5, nQuadSegs = 30)
```
:::


`st_area()` will compute the area of the buffers and generate an AREA column for buffer_cycling


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
buffer_cycling$AREA <- st_area(buffer_cycling)
```
:::


To derive total land, `sum()` is used


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
sum(buffer_cycling$AREA)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
1774367 [m^2]
```
:::
:::


## 1.7.2 Point in Polygon Count

> **Scenario**
>
> A pre-school service group want to find out the numbers of pre-schools in each Planning Subzone.

Preschools within each planning subzone are identified using `st_intersects()`. The number of preschools in each subzone is then calculated using `Length().` 


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz3414$`PreSch Count`<- lengths(st_intersects(mpsz3414, preschool3414))
```
:::

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
summary(mpsz3414$`PreSch Count`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
   Min. 1st Qu.  Median    Mean 3rd Qu.    Max. 
   0.00    0.00    4.00    7.09   10.00   72.00 
```
:::
:::


`top_n()` will find the planning subzone with the highest number of pre-schools


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
top_n(mpsz3414, 1, `PreSch Count`)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Simple feature collection with 1 feature and 16 fields
Geometry type: MULTIPOLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 39655.33 ymin: 35966 xmax: 42940.57 ymax: 38622.37
Projected CRS: SVY21 / Singapore TM
  OBJECTID SUBZONE_NO     SUBZONE_N SUBZONE_C CA_IND PLN_AREA_N PLN_AREA_C
1      189          2 TAMPINES EAST    TMSZ02      N   TAMPINES         TM
     REGION_N REGION_C          INC_CRC FMEL_UPD_D   X_ADDR   Y_ADDR SHAPE_Leng
1 EAST REGION       ER 21658EAAF84F4D8D 2014-12-05 41122.55 37392.39   10180.62
  SHAPE_Area                       geometry PreSch Count
1    4339824 MULTIPOLYGON (((42196.76 38...           72
```
:::
:::


Paramters of top_n:

-   x: DataFrame

-   n: Number of rows to return

-   wt: Ordering

## 1.7.3 Density of Pre-schools by Planning Subzones

Use `st_area()` to derive the area of each planning subzone.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz3414$Area <- mpsz3414 %>%
  st_area()
```
:::


`mutate()` will compute density and create “PreSch Density” column.


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
mpsz3414 <- mpsz3414 %>%
  mutate(`PreSch Density` = `PreSch Count`/Area * 1000000)
```
:::


# 1.8 EDA

## 1.8.1 Histogram

Plotting a histogram using `hist()` from base R


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
hist(mpsz3414$`PreSch Density`)
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-26-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## 1.8.2 ggplot2 Library


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data = mpsz3414,
       aes(x = as.numeric(`PreSch Density`))) +
    geom_histogram(bins = 20,
                   color = "darkgrey",
                   fill = "lavender") +
    labs(title = "Are pre-schools evenly distributed in Singapore?",
         subtitle = "There are many planning sub-zones with a single pre-school, on the other hand, \nthere are two planning sub-zones with at least 20 pre-schools",
         x = "Pre-school density (per km sq)",
         y = "Frequency")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-27-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::


## 1.8.3 Scatterplot


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(data = mpsz3414,
       aes(y = `PreSch Count`,
            x = as.numeric(`PreSch Density`))) +
    geom_point(color = "darkorange",
               fill = "mintcream") +
    xlim(0, 40) +
    ylim(0, 40) +
    labs(title = "Are pre-schools evenly distributed in Singapore?",
         x = "Pre-school density (per km sq)",
         y = "Pre-school count")
```

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](Hands-on_Ex01_files/figure-html/unnamed-chunk-28-1.png){width=672}
:::
:::
